PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Persistent bronchopleural fistula (BPF) with prolonged air leak, post right upper lobectomy for lung cancer (POD #14)

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial valve placement for bronchopleural fistula/air leak closure

INDICATION: 66-year-old male status post right upper lobectomy for stage IIA squamous cell carcinoma 14 days ago, complicated by persistent air leak via chest tube (continuous, >500mL/breath). CT chest shows persistent right apical pneumothorax with bronchial stump intact but suspected peripheral alveolar-pleural fistula in the remaining RML/RLL. Given poor surgical candidacy for re-thoracotomy (COPD, recent surgery, poor nutritional status), endobronchial valve placement was planned for non-surgical management of the air leak.

NOTE: This is NOT a BLVR procedure for emphysema/lung volume reduction. The indication is therapeutic air leak closure in the setting of BPF.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia (TIVA) with single-lumen ETT

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:
Patient [REDACTED] positioned supine. Flexible bronchoscopy performed. Airway inspection revealed:
- Trachea: Normal
- Right bronchial stump: Healing well, no gross leak
- Right bronchus intermedius: Patent
- Right middle lobe: Patent, normal appearance
- Right lower lobe: Segmental bronchi appeared inflamed but patent
- Left lung: Normal

Balloon occlusion testing was performed to id[REDACTED] the leaking segment. Sequential balloon occlusion of right lower lobe segments revealed:
- RB6 (superior segment): Partial reduction in air leak
- RB7-10 (basal segments): Further reduction with RB9 occlusion
- Combined RB6 + RB9 occlusion: Complete cessation of air leak

Based on balloon occlusion testing, decision was made to place endobronchial valves in RB6 and RB9.

Valve placement:
1. RB6 (superior segment): Zephyr 4.0mm EBV deployed. Good fit, no air flow around valve.
2. RB9 (lateral basal segment): Zephyr 4.0-LP EBV deployed. Good fit.

Post-valve bronchoscopy confirmed valves in good position. Patient's chest tube placed to water seal at end of procedure.

Immediate post-procedure assessment showed COMPLETE CESSATION of air leak on the chest tube drainage system.

DEVICES:
- Zephyr EBV 4.0mm x 1 (RB6)
- Zephyr EBV 4.0-LP x 1 (RB9)

SPECIMENS: None

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: Minimal

DISPOSITION: Return to thoracic surgery floor. Chest tube to water seal. If no air leak for 48 hours, will remove chest tube.

FOLLOW-UP: Will monitor for valve expectoration. Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks for potential valve removal if air leak remains resolved. Valves may be permanent if necessary.
